Award.AwardTitle: Advanced Manufacturing Project-Learning in Focused Innovation (AMPLiFI)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is creating a flexible technician education framework that draws on the experience of the National Network Manufacturing Institutes (NNMIs) to prepare the workforce for the advanced manufacturing technical occupations of the future. The framework is being developed and piloted for curricular materials focused on Additive Manufacturing (AM) in a manner that is broadly applicable to technician education programs in other technical areas to be determined under the NNMI program. In addition the framework and associated knowledge, skills and competencies are being built around broadly accepted national and international standards (e.g. ASTM, ISO) in order to ensure broad industry recognition and acceptance. A series of workshops centered on deploying 6 modules across a variety of existing courses in AM are being held, and these are serving as the baseline for evaluating the efficacy of the framework.

Intellectual Merit :
Emerging advanced manufacturing educational efforts traditionally lag behind the required technician competencies in the industrial sector, which increases the shortage of qualified technicians and slows the adoption of new advanced manufacturing technologies. This project is establishing a system for the creation of educational support materials that can be accelerated into the educational marketplace. It is anticipated that this model can be replicated and utilized to seamlessly integrate and align technician education to new emerging technologies that mature out of the NNMI efforts. This project is providing a framework to structure the technical educational elements and streamline the delivery format for technical education while addressing the needs of an industry driven technically competent workforce.

Broader Impacts :
The materials utilize components of deeper learning to engage students from a broad variety of cultural and socio-economic demographics. Students solve complex engineering related issues through a process that fosters a sense of ownership as well as responsibility. Project personnel work closely with an Industry Advisory Council (IAC) comprised of industry stakeholders to identify appropriate content, and the IAC is providing ideas that capture the regional applications of advanced manufacturing. The flexible framework model is maximizing integration into existing curriculum materials by creating modules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Additive Manufacturing (AM) can be a fantastic stand alone or supportive technology, allowing rapid development and iteration in a broad range of fields from engineering and art, to medicine and business, and many others.  Bringing greater exposure to the AM field and its technologies to a broad audience enables many other fields to reap the benefits of quick prototypes, novel designs, previously unmanufacturable parts, and more.

The primary goal of the AMPLiFI project was to create a flexible technician education framework to help prepare the technical workforce for the advanced and additive manufacturing technical occupations of the future. The primary goal was to develop discrete instructional material modules that could be digitally distributed and dropped into nearly any related class or viewed alone. The six modules we created were: Intro to Additive Manufacturing (AM), the Additive Manufacturing Process Chain, Design for Additive Manufacturing, Secondary Processes in Additive Manufacturing, Material Extrusion based Additive Manufacturing, and Vat Photopolymerization based Additive Manufacturing.

Over the grant period we presented the module materials in a host of classes and training events centered around the RapidTech (the former NSF ATE National Center for Rapid Technologies) lab at University of California Irvine (UCI). The developed materials were refined through continued use in the UCI Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (MAE) 195 Additive Manufacturing class as well as other opportunities.  The MAE 195 class was held 3 times per year and capped at 20 students per quarter to guarantee substantial hands on time with the manufacturing resources of the facility (RapidTech).  Outside of the MAE 195 class, the Intro to Additive Manufacturing presentation was used in numerous guest lectures, presentations for other classes, and workspace/lab tours. The material extrusion instructional content was developed and tested through the UCI Summer Bridge program which focuses on introducing incoming Community College transfer students to hands on project resources at the university. In this manner, we were able to test the material and delivery methods to a variety of audiences with different educational backgrounds.

With each module, we created, piloted, and refined different hands on projects for both lab and deeper learning exercises, focusing on entry-level technology platforms and utilizing free-to-use software packages when possible in order to be useful to the broadest possible audience.  We also created step-by-step, narrated video recordings of the processes that can be shared electronically, allowing distance learners access to the demonstrations even if they don’t have access to the equipment.  Electronic assets will be shared on the newly developed UCI Institute for Design and Manufacturing (IDMI) website (manufacturing.uci.edu), accessible to the public, academia, and industry alike. The modularized nature of the material allows educators to bring an individual module into a class for a single period/session without needing to dedicate an entire course to the subject matter at hand.  The ability to do so allows instructors to easily test new materials and the suitability for additive in an engaging way with very little cost or risk. In addition to this, with modules being complete lesson packages (lesson plans, assignments, videos, etc.), instructors can bring in material for their students that they themselves may not have a background in.

The material developed in the grant offers greater exposure to the AM field and its technologies than would traditionally be available to schools and people with limited means or access to a proper AM lab.  When a module is brought into such an environment the increased hands on experience through lab exercises builds real world skill and reinforces the knowledge learned in the lecture based portion of the presentation material.  Presented information was refined from both education and industry feedback to bolster effectiveness in creating a more knowledgeable and skilled AM user base.

With the AMPLiFI material and AM technologies, students have another tool with which to solve challenges.  AM is not an end all be all solution, however when properly applied it can allow for rapid development and advancement in problem solving at a pace far quicker than possible with traditional manufacturing.  Knowing when and how to use additive manufacturing allows students to quickly develop new ideas into new products, develop tools and aides in support of traditional manufacturing, and create custom tailored objects and devices where none were available or were prohibitively expensive or time consuming to do so before, be they custom tailored prosthetics and surgical guides or more efficient rocket nozzles.
